Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GeoGONAF: Analysis of active deformation and strain transfer along the Izmit Bay-Marmara Sea segment of the North Anatolian Fault
Award.AbstractNarration:
There are few places in the world that more closely match the seismic hazard potential of the San Francisco Bay Area of California than the Marmara Sea area of Turkey. In both places a magnitude 7 earthquake threatens to shake a maritime megacity. The current population of Istanbul is approaching 15 million, with an annual tourist population of 3 million, and the probability of an M7.1 earthquake in the next 20 years estimated as 35-70%. In 1766 a previous earthquake, similar to the one anticipated, destroyed Istanbul when its population was less than 0.5M. Some believe that a repeat of this earthquake is imminent. GeoGONAF is an acronym for an international collaborative project to monitor the subterranean and submarine strain changes that will precede the earthquake. Its scientific team does not expect to predict the precise time of this future earthquake, but they are optimistic that the dense array of monitoring instruments now listening closely to the approaching rupture will capture a rich harvest of signals that will indicate which of the several branches of the North Anatolian fault is most likely to rupture. It has taken the better part of decade to install these instruments around the city and on offshore islands, but now a stream of data flows into laboratories in Turkey, Germany and the US, that in principle permit the scientific teams of these collaborating nations to identify signals characteristic of approaching rupture. Lessons learned in Turkey will have direct application in the interpretation of similar precursory processes occurring beneath the Hayward fault located in the San Francisco Bay.

Six strain-meters were installed in boreholes during the final phase of GeoGONAF (the Geodetic component of the Geophysical Observatory to study the North Anatolian Fault near Istanbul). The strain-meters can detect strain changes of 10e-12 (1 picostrain), equivalent to a change in the diameter of the Earth of one fifth of the diameter of a human hair. The stabilization phase following inserting these ultra-sensitive instruments at depths of 30 m to 100 m underground is almost over (1-3 years) and six streams of strain data at 100 Hz sampling rate (as of June 2016) now complement data from the borehole seismometers and GPS instruments installed by the German, US and Turkish collaborators of GeoGONAF. The current project plans first to calibrate the strain-meters using tides and inbound seismic waves, and then to monitor episodic and continuous signals occurring in the Marmara region. Specifically a search for slow slip events on the submarine faults south and southeast of Istanbul is planned. These slow creep events are invisible to seismometers but are seen as increments on GPS data and as distinctive time-evolving signals on strain-meters with durations of minutes to days. On 18 March 2016 a large slow slip events on the first of the six strain-meters to be commissioned was captured in remarkable detail, its importance being that such events incrementally advance rocks already poised for imminent rupture towards a future earthquake. Although each increment brings an earthquake closer, it is too early to know on which of three faults south of Istanbul this will occur. The proposed project will examine incoming strain and GPS data on a daily basis to search for coherent signals occurring synchronously on the array of sensors, in order to identify slipping patches of faults and the area and extent of their slip. Preliminary interpretations indicate that large creep events cannot occur more than once per year on any given patch of a fault but that creep events may be quite frequent throughout the interconnected network of faults beneath and near the Sea of Marmara. As part of a larger study of the fault system additional surface creep-meters will be installed specifically to identify the propagation characteristics of 2-16 mm amplitude creep-events along the North Anatolian fault to the east of Marmara.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "earthquake cycle" is generally understood to consist of two main periods: the time between earthquakes when faults are being loaded by tectonic forces ("inter-seismic"); and the earthquake rupture itself, which releases this pent-up energy ("co-seismic"). After intense observation and study of large earthquakes over the last 30 years, such as the 1999 Izmit earthquake in north-west Turkey, it is clear that the period immediately following such earthquakes contributes significantly to the movement on a fault. This "post-seismic" period may last anywhere from days to years and has been observed to consist of continued, very slow slip on the fault after the main rupture. However, we are only just beginning to realize that such continued "afterslip" may occur not only immediately following an earthquake but in discrete or even continuous "creep" episodes throughout the period between earthquakes. Such events have a direct impact on our understanding of the location, timing and hazard associated with faults capable of producing damaging earthquakes and therefore requires dedicated study.

A major part of this project was to observe such episodic phenomena along the North Anatolian Fault through the Sea of Marmara, just south of Istanbul, in Turkey. We used two types of scientific instruments: one that measures ground motions directly using navigation satellite data, such as GPS; and another that measures the strain in the crustal rocks directly, which results from tectonic loading and release due to earthquakes and creep on faults. The latter "strainmeters" are much more sensitive than the former GPS instruments but they are more difficult and expensive to install in such great numbers. We also continued to process data from a network of the GPS instruments that has been maintained and expanded with our colleagues in Turkey over the last 20 years since the Izmit earthquake.

Several new GPS and strainmeter instruments were installed at locations along the North Anatolian Fault and subsidiary faults parallel to it. Some creep events were detected, supporting the hypothesis that such manner of tectonic strain release is not only expected but likely common. This is a significant discovery, and the frequency and relationship in time and space between these events remains to be determined with denser observations over a longer time period. Ultimately, the goal is to understand how these episodic events may influence the more well known parts of the earthquake cycle - the tectonic loading and release during major earthquakes.

Reanalysis and extension of the GPS data allows nearly 20 years of continued motion after the 1999 Izmit earthquake to be analysed. This is important because the Izmit earthquake remains one of the most well observed earthquakes - before, during and after the event - to date. Furthermore, it occurred on a segment of the North Anatolian Fault immediately adjacent to that which is just offshore of Istanbul. We found from the extended period of analysis that the surface motion observations may be explained by a form of fault "healing" after the earthquake, whereby the uppermost and lower portions of the fault, which did not slip as much in the earthquake as at mid-depths, have to catch up with the slip during the earthquake. This afterslip motion seems to continue to slowly decelerate over years, returning ultimately, we assume, to the state in which it was before the 1999 earthquake. This is also a key component of the earthquake cycle because it shows how different parts of a fault behave at different times, which again impacts our understanding of the hazard directly posed by earthquakes.

Finally, during the course of this project, several other moderate earthquakes occurred further west along the Aegean coastal border between Turkey and Greece. Detailed analysis of these events, using our GPS observations and processing results, and seismological work conducted by our Turkish colleagues, revealed patterns regarding where major slip occurs during an earthquake and inter-seismic signatures. Our current hypothesis, developed as part of this project, is that it may be possible to determine the area of major slip during earthquakes based on the relationship between pre-and post-earthquake seismicity and slip patches on the fault. These "asperity" areas may also relate to the development of afterslip patterns, as evidenced in the reanalysis of afterslip following the 1999 Izmit earthquake, as well as patterns of small background earthquakes between major events. If such spatial relationships can be established more confidently, this may be a way to understand which parts of a fault, in depth and along its length, are more likely to rupture in major events in the future, and allow us to identify segments of the fault for focused observations and place better constraints of the likely size, location and frequency of such events.
